text: hey everyone don't respond to weirdos
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a
review of this new ed sheeran album
equals this is a brand new lp from the
man himself uk singer and songwriter mr
ed sheeran and this is his latest in his
series of mathematically titled studio
albums ed's pretty world famous at this
point i think he needs no introduction
and it's also
no secret that i've not been the biggest
fan of his stuff up until this point and
i didn't exactly go into this new lp
with super high hopes especially with
the teasers being so derivative but i
will say a couple of things first
stylistically it does seem like ed is
kind of picking up where he left off on
his last record divide where variety was
kind of the name of the game sure there
are some pretty bare ballads in the
track list on this record but there are
also cuts that are indebted to dance pop
r b secondly i think this record has a
pretty strong start to it a song that
lyrically sets the tone for the entire
project too of course i'm talking about
the song tides which is a driving rock
cut with blaring guitars and tender
choruses plus loads of lyrics about how
ed's perspective has changed since
becoming a father and a husband and he's
now looking forward to what's to come
and better days it's a very hopeful and
aspirational track and while it is safe
there is a sincerity to it that i like a
lot however there is one line on the
track that really stuck out to me i lost
the confidence in who i was too busy
trying to chase the high and get the
numbers up and like what what time
exactly are we referring to here what is
the time frame in which ed was doing
this is it now is it present day because
chasing the high and getting the numbers
up and aping a bunch of trendy sounds
and popular music in a painfully
impersonal way is exactly what this
record does what is the song shivers if
not exactly that it's a plucky and bland
piece of dance pop with loads of fancy
instrumentation flirty romantic and
cloying lyrics as well wanting to kiss
your eyes and drink that smile kind of
feels like another attempt at a track
that might hit in the same way shape of
you did then there's the glitzy and
soaring bad habits which when i first
heard it i thought was the most
desperate attempt at hopping on this
very moody nocturnal pop wave a lot of
the weekend that was until i heard the
track overpass graffiti which is even
more indebted to this 80s revivalism
wave right now i feel like i'm listening
to the literal backing beat to aha's
take on me but just a different song's
been thrown on top of it which i guess
in a way is fine there's nothing wrong
in general with some musical nostalgia
but ed is doing it in a way where he's
just
stripping all the fun out of doing a
throwback track where's the melodrama
where are the fun bubbly synths or
anything like that i mean again it does
have a bit of an 80s new wave backbone
but everything on top of that is just a
pure millennial pop slop around the
halfway point of the lp even the
instrumentals start to take a nosedive
for example leave your life i think has
one of the most touching sentiments on
the entire lp but lord does this beat
sound cheap where did the beats and beat
boxing perks and bedroom synths on this
track come from the whole thing sounds
the way that eating boiled pasta
straight out of the strainer tastes then
there are similar issues on the track
collide where did the perks on this one
come from banging on a desk and
capturing it on a laptop mic plus the
enya ass synths flying in every
direction on the hook i'm not
into it now i do like the lyrical angle
of the track i think it's pretty cute
how ed goes through all these things
that him and his wife have been through
going to the hospital with broken bones
going to an irish bar in rome again it's
quaint it's fine but then ed uh hits us
with the line uh shared a toothbrush and
shared a home
edward no look i'm no prude but this is
a little too freaky for me you're in
love and that's fine and i get that but
you're swapping the instrument that you
use to like
you know dig old food particles from
like in your teeth you're you're sharing
that the mastering on the song two step
is kinda awful even though i slightly
get it this is one where ed goes a
little hip hop rapping ed is back on
this one with some of those tight speedy
flows and of course that sub bass is
just
roaring to the point where it's almost
clipping and just drowning out
everything else in the mix but the
biggest instrumental shock on this lp
comes in the form of the song sandman
which honest to god sounds like a cutesy
instrumental bed that you would hear
underneath uh an instructional video on
youtube i guess there's something
intentionally childlike about it given
that the song is a tribute to his
daughter but the instrumental is so
infantile in the most obvious and
marketable way like that royalty-free
ukulele and glockenspiel instrumental
we've all heard a million times on this
platform is more intricate with stop the
rain ed does his best vocally to pull
off some michael jackson style riffs he
does get closer than i expected but
ultimately only ends up sounding like a
few shades away from corey feldman doing
his best michael jackson impersonation
now look there are some more stripped
back tracks in the track list that i
thought were a lot more appealing the
guitar and piano combo on first times is
quite nice sure the track is packed with
more overly sentimental lyrics but at
least it's cute once again there is
something about ed's sincerity that
helps him overcome some of the aesthetic
and compositional shortcomings of his
writing get ready to hear this song at a
wedding or two over the next year then
there's the uh the joker and the queen a
real sigma anthem on this one you could
fall for a thousand kings when i fold
you see the best in me the joker and the
queen the track does sound like a bit
much with all the you know disney
soundtrack strings wailing away in the
background but i actually do think the
song features a strong tune some pretty
clever writing as well with all the
illusions to card playing plus the
seeing the best in me line does tie in
really well to the whole joker thing
considering like you know the role the
joker would play in a round of poker
then there's visiting hours where ed is
seen flirting with a bit of country
music and
lyrically this track kills me i i love
it it may in fact be my most favorite ed
sheeran song ever by a long shot i wish
that evan had visiting hours
and you know tell you the news and
we're talking about all the things that
you're missing since you passed it's
honestly just a beautiful feeling plus
the grand rushes of vocal harmonies on
the track make for some of the most
beautiful moments on the entire project
too it's just a really pretty song with
a simple and beautiful sentiment yeah it
does have almost like a a hallmark card
kind of vibe to it but you know every
once in a while
those do bang there is a context in
which that kind of works makes sense has
a point and i do think there are spots
on this lp where ed hits that nail on
the head but those are rare moments on
this project the vast majority of the
time what equals does is
just do a piss-poor job of presenting a
mediocre singer songwriter album as a
pop album and look i get there's a huge
market out there for ed's pop tracks
there's no denying that it's just a
little aggravating knowing that ed can't
get any of his pop songs across without
blatantly ripping off a superior song or
artist in the process it would be one
thing if i felt like ed's tunes were
bringing something wild and new and
innovative or even like um i don't know
flavorful to pop music but i just don't
think it is i'm feeling a strong two to
a light three on this one tran position
have you given this album a listen did
you love it did you hate it what would
you rate it you're the best you're the
best what should i i review next hit the
like if you like please subscribe and
please don't cry hit the bell as well
over here next to my head is another
video that you could check out hit that
up or the link to subscribe to the
channel anthony fantano ed sheeran
forever
